Why?
 
 If the Democrats are serious about winning the white house why out of the 9 Democratic potentials did they pick Kerry?
 
 I said from the beginning that a good choice for the Democrats would be lieberman. When discussing this with liberals, I recieved that answer that he was too moderate. And so I accepted this as an answer.
 
 But now as the general election looms isn't the goal of both contenders to appear as moderate as possible in order to win independent votes? So why not go with Lieberman in the first place?
 
 Kerry is stiff and lacks emotion, and he also considerably liberal. 
 
 Would not Edwards (who during the primaries won many more votes independent votes than Kerry) or Lieberman have been a better pick for Dem. nominee?
daewoo

I think they voted their hearts, not their heads (a common liberal failing). There were democrat canidates who could have taken swing voters, there were even democratic canidates who could have taken disenfranchised republican voters. Kerry is not one of them. Now, those republicans who feel bush failed them will be voting for him again (or maybe third party) and swing voters who vote their head can be expected to avoid kerry like the plague.
 
 I suppose he must be counting on the folks who would vote for a reterded monkey over bush. I hope there are not really that many blind people in this country. Personally, I would rather have clinton, buush I, or even reagn (alzheimers and all) than wither of our current choices.

Why ask why. Why are the Republicans re-nominating George Bush? The US supreme court had to step in and hand him the election in 2000. After 3.5 years he's left us with the Iraq war, fewer jobs, and an economy that's as fragile as a crystal vase. In addition, the polls have him continually struggling to keep pace with Kerry. If the election were held today, he probably wouldn't win. Unfortunately, pride prevents party members from making changes, and backing the incumbent is easier than admitting you made the wrong choice the first time.

 The growth of the economy is relative to what sector you fall into. The Dow was a little over 9900 today, down probably 700 points from this years high. georged

Our government spends many, many millions of dollars polishing those numbers to sooth the public. All the economists quoted are either government employees or brokerage house sources. If you want to look at the economy with an objective eye, go into the GDP numbers and look at the contributions from consumer and government spending based on debt. Tell me how long that can be sustained. New jobs? Nice warm feeling about government new job numbers is that unlike those filing for unemployment benefits, new job numbers don't say what kind of jobs, nor do they have a breakdown of how many are government jobs (fastest growing sector of the economy and it never decreases) or related to the burgeoning military support industry (tax dollars) created by Iraq. Interest rates? The only normal reason interest rates rise is because demand creates competition for the dollars, a market force. Raising them because inflation is rearing its head due to a weak dollar and demand by foreign investors for more interest (we're at less than half the rest of the developed world) is considered reason enough. Real rising interest rates would be created by expansion demand of the industrial sector, which would also create accompanying jobs. Take a look at what a 1% fed interest increase will do in reducing the number of people who can qualify for a new home, our only thriving industry. Deficit spending, etc.? 
 
 At this point, Homer Simpson is looking better and better as a candidate

Who said anything about always trusting the government? That's a terrible idea. The government lies about things, too, and will try to mislead you often.
 
 It's one thing to trust them and another to not believe a single thing they say. That's absurd. 
 
 If something were wrong with those numbers it would be a scandal that every anchor in the country would be covering and it'd be ratings paradise. The Democrats would pound it to get Kerry elected. So on and so forth.
 
 But you have no evidence to say that those numbers are wrong, you're just saying you don't believe them.
georged

But you have no evidence to say that those numbers are wrong, you're just saying you don't believe them.

 
 I'm saying I do believe them. I'm saying their underlying composition expresses a level of comfort to the public that doesn't exist. No government, newspaper, investor group or other entity that depends on public support is going to sit the American public down and say 'Look, this is all wrong and you're going to have to fix it or suffer eventual financial chaos'. The last person(s) who would tell that to the public would be a challenging politician who hopes to gain office as he/she would have to offer solutions to the dilemma as a major plank in their campaign platform. You don't open a can of worms unless you have a solution, especially to a public as naïve and uninformed as ours is. This is the land of more is better through massive personal debt and no personal savings, which is a big contributor to those highly polished GDP numbers every politician and would-be politician lives by.
